v8DqZKix4bZhHugHraaf1g.text: Place is delicious! I love their vegetarian menu. It beats a lot of other pho restaurants. Especially on my side of town.

aewyl1iSgpF8-zEELJ1OLA.text: call it new owner or whatever, go to this place if:  (lets see if can do this without using profanity)    1  you're SUPER hungry, otherwise food tastes nasty (meat has gross smell like dirty socks... broth tastes like water that the staff washed their hands in).   Tip:  bring LISTERINE  2  you need to get out of the sun (for the air conditioner) to see a kid waiter in sandals  drive 20 mins to Pho #1

u2JecAlCDKOqv9csB17wmQ.text: Hey, the owners are really nice the waiters are assholes.  I don't think so, I am not gonna spend money in a place where a sneer from some waiter is deemed a reply to any questions.  And they do not have vegetarian pho.  The pho is passable just because chinatown is so far away.  But, pho saigon 8 opened across the street so, I go there and the pho is good like in chinatown.  (they also have vegetarian pho and good spring rolls)

At4Sy8_h4-MhFQOtJgkIdw.text: Service started out okay, but after we were served it went down hill. No water refills and after asking twice for a fork and napkins we still never got them. I wanted to like this place because of the good reviews but the service ruined it for us. We were never asked if we needed anything, we just sat there waiting for them to come to our table and towards the end we got what we needed by waving at them. Will not be back.

aXMhdSc8XtIAkdAqDxftQQ.text: There are more Vietnamese Restaurants in Las Vegas than in Hollywood or Silverlake, California.   I looked at the Yelp reviews and became determined to sample at least one before leaving.  I chose Lemongrass Cafe because it had the highest amount of reviews than any other in town.   Also, found that some reviewers chose to explain that their new Vietnamese restaurant is even better than this place.   I had to try it.    I arrived about 4 pm on Feb 19th.  There was only one other table being served in the whole restaurant - perfect.  I'm not scared.     The servers barely speak English - another good sign.   I did not like the size of the menu.  Come on,  make a few incredible dishes and leave the books for the library.   I became overwhelmed with choices.  I had to pull out my Vons $10.00 magnifying glasses to read.  The lighting could improve but I'm not so concerned about interior design.  Although the 1950s malt shop/dinner takes away from the rich Vietnamese scents and cultural paraphernalia.    I ordered the vegetarian Pho with tofu #59 - Large $8.95   Also dared to ask for "make your own shrimp and vegetable rice paper wraps"  off the menu. I figured he understood that it was for me, but since I did not explain, he brough a huge order for way more than one person and hit me with a $19.70 charge.   Ouch !    My friend Meese ordered the number 39 Pho Tai / Rare Beef Pho - Large 7.95 and a coke.    The off the menu wraps were the best I've ever had.   The noodles were perfectly cooked.  The vegetables, crisp, bright and very fresh.   Plenty of herbs, flowering basil, mint, cilantro, sliced cucumbers, (Boston?) lettuce, and about 20 pieces of perfectly cooked grilled shrimp.   The table had a home made spicy chili - a great compliment for spiciness.   I polished that plate like Homer Simpson eating a box of doughnuts.   The Pho surprisingly was not as hot as I'm used to having it, however, I had no problem with it.  Normally, Pho upon arrival has to be carefully sipped at the beginning, otherwise you end up with charring of your tongue and mouth.   I was able to dive in free from danger and just inhale it RTC Navy style.    I should have asked for the cost of any off menu items.  When the server handed the check to me, there was a little bit of hesitation  and a concerned look in his eyes as if that (*&^%$# ) pulls that stuff all the time.    It is still my fault for not asking the price.   When I return to Vegas, I will definitely explore all the well rated Vietnamese restaurants.

0UjEsfeSkK26S8thpXbSfA.text: After searching on Yelp, we decided to try this restaurant yesterday when we were in Las Vegas. We ordered 2 bowls of Pho and we were very disappointed 1) They brought a plate of Soy bean sprout and the basil leaves. The bean sprouts were not fresh and the basil leaves were all had BLACK spot in almost each leaf.  2) the soup is supposed to be the soul of Pho dish, it was watery with no taste of Beef Soup at all

ht_NOmVX_KDLSzbSc6iVOA.text: Although I proclaim Vietnamese food is one of my all time favorites, if not the favorite, I can never get myself to go to a Vietnamese restaurant. Growing up with a chef for a dad, and a mom that can rival him in this cuisine, makes me never want to pay for something that they can cook better. Anytime pho is mentioned, I find eight friends lining up at the front door.  Finally giving in and taking the advice of various friends, I came to this converted 50's diner. When you walk in, you are greeted by the conflicting smell of Vietnamese food and the shell of the western world. Not much has changed in aesthetics besides the few scattered Asian trinkets and framed artwork.  The food is a little pricier than you will find in Chinatown, but I do not have to drink a gallon of water to subdue the side effects of MSG overload. I am not saying that they don't use any, it just isn't as noticeable. My group had ordered spring rolls. They were on the small side, but the flavors were all there. I swear I tasted mint in there and that is an ingredient that some places neglect to include and it is a shame. I had ordered the lotus salad. This was exactly what I was craving. Light, flavorful, cool and not greasy. The perfect meal for the summer months. The salad consists of lotus stems, jicama, mint, onions, shrimp, and pork served with a tamarind sauce and shrimp crackers. If you like the Vietnamese version of papaya salad, you would probably like this as well. When it is the middle of July, you will not be in the mood for a big bowl of pho, but know there are still options.

g8_9AD3Wfx5fs8cWHxB7tQ.text: Their Pho Thai is as good as it gets around here!   I walked in here and was hit with the familiar and authentic beefy, brothy, and oniony smell.  Siiigh.  Smells like the pho joints at home (I grew up in Asia town in SoCal)!   I'm thinking, "I like this place already." I ordered a small Pho Thai and it fed me really well.  There were lots of noodles and onions (which I LOVE) and the broth was clear and had a subtle flavor that I'm normally accustomed to, but it was still yummy, nonetheless.  You can't really f*ck up pho, and  for around $7 it's one of the cheapest places you can get pho in the Vegas area.  My group ordered the chicken spring rolls and they were delicious as well.  The peanut sauce complemented the spring rolls nicely, while the fried, crunchy  egg roll skin inside the spring roll itself added a great contrast in texture.   Their menu is relatively large and has the Vietnamese classics like goi cuon (spring rolls), banh xeo (Vietnamese pancake/omelette), and che ba mau (three-color dessert).    I will return. :)

yFoSHhgeNA56PR0tAc5XPg.text: The friendliest and most attentive wait staff I've seen in years. A rare find! The food is delicious and the portions are generous, making prices reasonable.

6Cj3F7XUUcucoi0qkfW3YA.text: Sorry, I love to try new things and perhaps I just ordered EVERYTHING wrong. But combined with the sewage smell when you walk in, the flavor of the meats being "off" I just can't recommend this to any other person.

cx-kBiGWwUjLPbJsagBiTg.text: Still as good as I remember. Tasty pho broth, yummy spring & summer rolls, and the must-have shaken beef. DELICIOUS! And the owners are so darn cute and friendly, they make us feel like we're part of their family :)

ZzHsMnj4p0GyWEm9laoyXQ.text: I had the lemongrass beef and eggroll, literally just one eggroll. I was pretty disappointed with my food and the eggroll just didn't taste right. Growing up in a town with a big Vietnamese community and eating at their restaurants on a regular basis, it's pretty safe to say lemongrass cafe's food is not that great in comparison and I'm probably not coming back.

KiUzcRoLGJpfWVi3xesfZg.text: Their pho tai was not bad. I got a size small and it filled me up. The soup wasn't very oily and pretty light to the taste. Their grilled pork rice plate wasn't so good. The grilled pork was a bit too oily and bland tasting. I felt like I was eatting something very fatty. I would come back to this place when I crave for pho because it's closer than other places and their pho isn't bad.

EaiLyWvB29SVtniv1X-frQ.text: I love this restaurant.  The best Vietnamese food we've found in Vegas.  We've only been here twice, but will definitely be going back for more.  Staff is very friendly, atmosphere is unpretentious.  Our last visit we had the seven courses of beef.  Delicious! Definitely recommend.

zRyb6doWG4gkyuzseTr1ow.text: Great pho! The broth is good and tasty, the meat was good and tender. I ordered the pho with everything in it and spring rolls for appetizer. I was pretty full walking out. The spring rolls were freshly made, alot of places pre-make it and you can tell then been sitting for awhile. The pho was really great. Coming from san jose, we usually eat pho at least once or twice a week. Here I haven't eaten pho since i left san jose. But I think i found a new place that is close by and the service is great. Very friendly, courteous and very, very clean. I used the coupon for 10% off, I didn't print it. I just told them about it and it was cool.  I will be back soon for a 2nd review.

5Alzh49iPSzoSD5-qdhOIQ.text: I'd like to reiterate everything I've said in the previous review.  This place is nice, well-lit, has soft music, is clean and fairly classy (not hole-in-the-wall-ish), has very very delicious food, friendly and non-overbearing staff, and so forth.  In my last review I mentioned that it was disappointing that they didn't have Vietnamese style sandwiches (banh mi).    But now they do!  And they're actually very good!  The bread is fresh and tasty, and they're pretty liberal with the meat filling, generous with the herbs and spices, and not overwhelming with the pickled daikon and carrots.  The taste is a little different than at Pho Thanh Huong, but the difference will be choosing between Coke and Pepsi instead of choosing between Coke and Crap.  Both are good in their own way, and preference will be simply a matter of taste, and not a matter of quality.  They are $3.75 each, $0.75 more than Pho Thanh Huong.  A few more specific recommendations:    The Pho of course is excellent, and I find it to be the best in Vegas so far.  At $7 for two people, can't beat the price (though other pho places are comparable, of course).  The Lime Soda is to die for!  Lots of sugar, and certainly not something to drink every day, but a must-have once a month or so!  My favorite appetizer is the Vietnamese Crepe, full of pork and shrimp and many other deliciousnesses, but it's a tad pricey at $8.  It's good for the table, though.  Second favorite appetizer is the regular Spring Rolls.  It has a nice crunch, it has both shrimp and pork, lots of vegetables, and of course they have the *best* peanut dipping sauce in any Vietnamese place I've tried yet.  These are only $6.  Go go go to Lemongrass!  I go there often, especially since it's about 9 minutes from my house.

Ox-eZqGM9s0_yBMnsE4nYA.text: Amazing shrimp spring rolls. I come here all the time, and there's something for everyone.. Vegetarian, pescetarian, carnivore.. It's always a reliable meal, cheap, healthy and tasty! Not necessary a romantic place though, since it's a converted 50's diner.

rjQEi0dAEsAtTDzVih2eTg.text: Great broth!  The broth didnt seem like the dumped MSG into it. Friendly service.    Sure.. theres pho saigon 8 like a block a way and it has yogurt land right next to it.. but it's not a far distance for better pho.

Z3RMXWvmljTPkvgUqtVM7g.text: Great service and great food a must try for anybody a fan of PHO or Vietnamese Very reasonable too!

VscpN9sfY2y4dtQ4tMup5Q.text: Pho Tai FEVER... The service here can be hit or miss but the Pho is always on point and their peanut sauce is my personal favorite. The owner might be the sweetest woman I have ever met.  So, if you're closer to Green Valley than you are to Spring Mountain, Lemongrass Cafe can cure your craving for Pho. They do offer a small and large serving which is always appreciated. Be aware, Lemongrass is nestled into a "diner" setting and can easily be passed for a breakfast joint.

9N73ayDJ1T1FZy1-4S5G-Q.text: Wish I could give zero stars. The worst service I have ever had. When we walked in it smelled gross, like old wet clothes left in a corner somewhere. The person that seated us did not even talk to us, just pointed at us and pointed at a table to sit. The place wasn't even busy. He was very rude when I asked about the items on the menu. Will never come back and it's a shame because it's so close to our house.

AztU2cFIbxFsVwuDrxoqPQ.text: This is our favorite Pho restaurant.  We used to go to Pho Saigon, but this place is way better.  The servers are polite..not like at Pho Saigon where they're always mad...lol...the food here is much better too. The soups are pretty comparable, but the vermicelli bowls are way better. In addition, Lemongrass has more space for its patrons. You dont have to sit arm's length from the next people. Overall Lemongrass is the better Pho restaurant and our personal favorite.  Highly suggest this place.

6vr7OI_PhgCgP0WbrBBZtw.text: I was quite impressed with the food here. The pho was very good and I had some kind of tamarind salad that was nothing short of amazing.   Now for service. Slow.... Very slow.... They clearly don't put an emphasis on service. Took forever to get our food and had to ask repeatedly for our check.   If it wasn't for the poor service I would have given them the extra 5th star. All in all the food was good enough for me to highly recommend.

uHD3coBM2AkH79MFnPdHZA.text: Pros: THE BEST food ever! Fresh tasting, great prices and a big variety (menu). Cons: No one smiles, very impersonal. I felt like they were doing me a favor by "letting" me eat in their establishment. The place also smells bad.

-mELxYYfmJCQ-cwV1rNITA.text: Food was OK , good for the price if you want a quick craving for pho' but service was rude and you feel very out of place and unwanted. I won't be going back

P1nSskeDhXrmafp0QQxhoQ.text: This place as everyone said is located in the 50s dinner. Been here for a couple of times, and tried the bun bo hue, pho, bbq rice plate and thai tea. The first time I came here, the bun bo hue was huge with lots of beef, pig knuckle, and other meat. It was tasty. However, on my most recent visit, I ordered the bun Bo hue again, and it was missing the pig knuckle, the waitress never came back to check on me and I was in a hurry so I didn't ask about it. I finished the food and was just sitting there for 5-10mins waiting for the bill, so I had decided to just go up and pay at the register.  Inconsistence order and crappy service.

qSolj6Xy3ucDWKztNvEawQ.text: A co-worker and I decided to try Lemongrass Cafe during our lunch break.  We are big fans of Vietnamese food and due to the fact that we could not reach our "go-to" place because of a car accident, Lemongrass Cafe was up the street and easy to get to.    They have a vast menu and after taking a look through it, we decided to try our favorites.  We shared the spring rolls which came out in a timely manner. They were delicious. It took a little longer for our entrees as we noticed some tables that ordered after us had received their food before us.  Nonetheless, the food was tasty.  I had pho with rare beef and well done brisket.  The flavor was great and the portion size filling.  My co-worker had the vermicelli with tofu and she said it was very good.  I see us going back again to give this place another try.

Jl7rMSQ5V4TqEDVjA6jmng.text: saw some crazily overpriced banh mi on TLC's best of sandwich show last night and was inspired  to try Lemongrass Cafe's finally.  still yummy...got the grilled beef with all the fixins' and a Thai iced tea to go.  This was delicious - I ate it while driving home.    The good: delicious flavor, fresh veggies, jalepenos, crispy bread, and for non-pork eaters, they have beef, chicken, egg, and veggie choices The not-so-good: $3.75 plus tax, way smaller than the $3 with tax banh mi at Pho Thanh Huong, and I got reprimanded for using my credit card for under $10 order (showed her proof that I had no cash)  needless to say, I will come back here because they have good food and it is affordable.  If I got another banh mi, I would try the fried egg one mmm!

hMsGu8-WINIAC9enuEXX3A.text: My mom and her friend wanted to try a Vietnamese place, so I found this one. Man, people weren't kidding when they said this was an old-style diner. It screams retro, except a lot of the interior decor is Vietnamese (not including the maneki neko).  I went with a large bowl of pho chin nam. I thought it was a 4/5. Pretty clean broth, nice noodles, but the meat for some reason lacked the depth of flavor that I'm accustomed to in California. Still, it's better than the pho at Pho Kim Long, which is supposed to be the go-to spot in the Vegas area. Also, the utensils - wooden chopsticks and somewhat light plastic - didn't have the solid feel of the tools that I'd wanna use at a pho place.  My mom and her friend had, respectively, a rice noodle dish with pork, shrimp, and egg rolls, and a hu tieu (noodle soup somewhat similar to pho). They didn't find it up to their standards really, maybe a 3/5. In addition, it was kinda annoying that it took pho and hu tieu longer than the noodles to come out. Pho definitely should not take that long to get ready if they have a broth going, which you'd think they would have at lunch hour (12:30).  I decided that the tiebreaker between 3 and 4 stars would be the com bo luc lac (shaking beef), which I often order at Vietnamese restaurants. I took one to-go and (my fault for waiting) the rice was kinda dry by the time I got around to eating dinner, However, I could tell that the rice was good when it was fresh, and the well-seasoned meat and the sauteed veggies were pretty darn good and still had great texture (tender and crunchy, respectively). I'll give it a 4.25/5, taking into account the time elapsed in the to-go box. Maybe it'd be closer to a 5 if It had been fresh, but I can't make that judgment  Locals may wanna note that management changed some time in Dec 2011, so if you didn't like it the last time, you might wanna try it again. This is probably about what you can expect out of a Vietnamese place not in California.

vE4VniMN4eC2q9omAJjCIg.text: Vegan/Vegetarian friendly!!!!  My family and I go here every week (2-3 times) for their vegetarian pho with vege and tofu (actually vegan because they use vege broth, fresh broccolis, carrots, onions, celery, tofu). You CAN ask for extra veggie and/or tofu for an extra charge. I sometimes do that n get no noddles if I want to eat really light.   I have to warn you, the vege phos usually take a little longer because they actually have to make the broth when you order but it is so worth the wait. It is so light but satisfying for us (note that I am not vegetarian and I order that everytime now). I actually brought some friends (meat eaters and vefetarians) and they enjoyed the vegetarian pho as well!   When i want to endulge myself a bit, I order their vegetarian spring rolls. I love to have them cut the rolls so that I can easily dunk em in the sauce and wrap the little pieces in the lettuce they provide. Well, I ask for extra lettuce, too.  Seriously love this place. I think I have been coming here ever since they opened. I used to have thier meat phos, seafood pho with egg noodles/glass noodles, rice dishes, etc. I recommend this place 100%.

qVWkSOiei2bXT3aw17ZYXw.text: Growing up in Orange County, CA, I had the opportunity of eating really good Vietnamese food. Just tried the Bun Bo Hue at Lemongrass and in my opinion, it is the best Bun Bo Hu I have ever had. If you are in Vegas and like Bun Bo Hue, you have to check this place out.

SWzS9pUiaSbmDt5aM95Bqg.text: I was so disappointed when I moved to Texas and left Lemongrass behind. This is truly one of the best authentic Vietnamese restaurants in Las Vegas. Excellent choices and they have vegetarian clear broth pho!!! I've been so happy since I've moved back and will never go anywhere but this place. If you're looking for some fast and quick low-quality then do NOT go to this restaurant. You will not appreciate it for what it is. Authentic.

p7ErZs2jVWlsaeeALtQZpA.text: Vietnamese restaurants usually NEVER compare with my homecooked meals, however Lemongrass was delightful! We managed to get back into LV before it closed after a weekend trip to OC.   I got a pseudo-broken rice (com tam) dish with bbq pork, cha, and cold-fresh veggies.   It's in a cute diner-style decor with good ambience and not as noisy.

lfPFnMoPIYvdc80B-xc6gQ.text: Just, no.    I got food here when I was in town for the weekend with some friends and we stayed at a house nearby.  I got: crispy egg rolls, grilled chicken banh mi, and a side of pho broth.  Egg rolls: Good, fresh, and I like that they were served with the lettuce and fresh mint leaves and cilantro.  Best way to eat them is to wrap them in the lettuce with the herbs and dip into the lemongrass sauce. Yum.  Banh mi: It was the SMALLEST banh mi I have ever seen, AND they charged $6.75 for it.  I've been a regular at various Vietnamese restaurants, both east coast and west coast for years - banh mi's are at least 30-40% bigger than theirs and cost around $4-$5.  Also, the grilled chicken inside was weirdly chopped up and not good quality.   Pho broth: This was the coup de grace of any good impression this restaurant could have made.  The broth tasted just like the CANNED beef broth you get at Asian supermakets with maybe some star anise added in - there was no depth or richness of flavor that comes from hours of simmering beef bones.  I will bet anyone $100 that this place doesn't make its stock the legit way.   It gets 2 stars because the service was friendly and because it inhabits what obviously used to be a Silver Diner - their food is definitely still better than whatever Silver Diner had.

bBUlVLIs24oOwKbxhwF4jw.text: Never seen a Vietnamese restaurant in an old diner, definitely threw me off for a while. I would've driven in circles before thinking this was the place.   So I walk in...it's pretty empty. I never like empty restaurants, it tells me what's going to come, normally a very bad time. No one was there to greet, so I decided to sit at the bar since I was dining alone that night. There was about ten customers total in this place. Took a while for someone to give me a menu, even though the waitresses passed me multiple times. After finally looking over the menu, I decided I wanted to try their spring rolls, and I really wanted a sandwich. Wanted to try the veggie Bahn Mi. After she brings me the rolls, she informs me that they are out of avocado. That's basically the main ingredient in the sandwich. I didn't really want much meat, so I agreed to basically a sandwich with some greenery in it.   Spring rolls with just shrimp were very good...although on the small side. The peanut sauce was very tasty as well. When my sandwich came...I noticed that it too was on the small side. Bread was good, just wish I had the full power of the veggie sandwich with all the ingredients.   So basically I left there hungry. Food was cheap tho...I might give them another shot.

uKomjCBbMFbZ94oX7EwYtQ.text: Omg pls do not go here.  1st time at lemongrass had bum Bo hue short rip. Look and decide

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass Café - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 3 dried up burnt small pieces of short rip with brown lettuce.
Photo of Lemongrass Café - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beautiful piece of vege in short rip

Ted71ubFYHrDHbAG8z4Xlw.text: So yummy! The waiter was a little sarcastic but it's ok because I am too. The food was phenomenal. I ate Pho with the rare steak and it was soooo delicious. The spring rolls were good along with the peanut sauce. The place is clean and the bathroom are as well.

ZQ8hIZ2bIq9I0pmHVxG1UQ.text: I have to say this place doesn't look anything like your typical Pho restaurant. You might even pass by and not even realize you can get some great pho here. So don't let looks deceive you, this place was pretty good. Probably my second choice for pho in Vegas. First being Pho Saigon 8 on spring mountain. It's called Lemongrass Cafe but it should be appropriately named Lemongrass Diner. A fellow Yelper described it as "Vietnamese Pulp Fiction"...my thoughts exactly honey bunny!! Now back to the food. I ordered pho tai, a small bowl as usual. Flavorful broth, not overly salty. I barely had to add any hot sauce to it, didn't need it. Took longer to arrive at my table than I'm used to but I didn't mind so much. 5 minutes isn't a big deal. All in all, pleasantly surprised. Great pho, I'll definitely be back again when I'm on that side of town. Thanks fellow Yelpers for this find. ; )

uFgFbkZnFfgigERmu212Yw.text: The food was decent, but have to agree with previous reviews. Looked like only 2 employees in the front and yes they were rude and almost seemed angry they were there. Service was slow, never checked on us, even had to wait for the check. I have been there in the past and agree there must have been an owner change, it had really gone downhill. With so many competing Vietnamese restaurants, don't know how they are going to last.  I'm out---

hMH_Kddv6p2FaBAIXyKATg.text: EXCELLENT FOOD! And, the sweet old woman made for the best service. Definitely coming back! And, they have binh xeo!

4k7dCQOB6iKcdZ-_RsaYwg.text: It's always surprising to find edible Pho places outside of Chinatown, for that I have to give Lemongrass Cafe credit for. This place resides in the former 5 & Dine Cafe and it's pretty interesting how they turned a once upon a time great diner into a Vietnamese cafe. Some of the decor is still leftover from the previous owner plus a touch of Asian decor.   I really enjoyed their Gi Xoai (Green Mango Salad). It was light & refreshing and the tamarind sauce balanced out the flavors wonderfully. This salad consisted of shredded green mango, shrimp, pork, roasted peanuts and fresh herbs. I recommend this salad for those who don't mind the different taste and don't want something too heavy.   Of course you can't have Vietnamese without ordering some pho, spring rolls and eggrolls. I thought both the spring rolls and eggrolls were good. The spring rolls could have used a little more flavor but the sauce made up for what the roll was missing.  I do think it's interesting that they do give you a couple options for different types of spring rolls and eggrolls.  Last but not least, I decided to try the seafood clear noodle soup rather than the pho. I must say, this was the most interesting thing I had ever eaten. Those clear noodles were sticking to the back of my throat that I was trying not to choke on them. I've had these noodles in Korean dishes but for some reason they were really hard to swallow. The best way to describe this feelign is just picture taking a sticky hand and slapping it on the wall. The broth was ok but I probably wouldn't order this dish again.   I would go to this place again to try their pho, banh mi and Kem Xoai Trai Vi (mango ice cream)! Prices were reasonable and for 2 people who were pretty hungry, we paid around $40. Oh before I forget complimentary ice/hot jasmine tea is always a wonderful thing and the staff wasn't too bad. So if you don't want to take a trip to Chinatown, just take a quick trip to Eastern & 215 and you can have the same experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass Café - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Green Mango Salad
Photo of Lemongrass Café - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp &amp; Pork Spring Rolls &amp; Three-Colored Dessert
Photo of Lemongrass Café - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Seafood Clear Noodle Soup

NITxTO8LLg47hCafj4XBaA.text: Pho (pronounced fuh) served in a diner? Yes and yes! On a cold Vegas day (and there seem to be many of these lately... not complaining, though...I love me some cute boots!!), there is nothing better than pho to warm your belly up. What Lemongrass may have on some of its other competitors (yes, Pho Saigon 8, I'm talking to you!) is that they have both veggie and meat broth options so that the non-meat eaters in the group (MOI, of course!) can also enjoy Vietnam's delish version of clear soup.   While Lemongrass' pho is indeed fantastic (shout out to the veggie-based pho with seafood), another menu star is their chao tom (shrimp and sugar cane rice paper rolls.... SALIVATION time!! The secret ingredient: red shiso. SLURP).   Lunch time here is a bit hectic so, if you go, be prepared to wait a little bit. That said, the wait is absolutely worth it!

MJ54icb-JXgXtURPzV8mzQ.text: Great place for Pho.  I think the place used to be some kind of 50's diner, which makes it a kind of interesting dining experience.  Not that it affects the food quality, but provides an interesting/strange contrast.    I usually get the rare beef pho, while my husband likes the brisket.  Both are good.  I can't quite put my finger on it, but I like this place better than Pho Saigon 8.  I think it may be the basil.  Or it may be that it's quieter.      The service here is pretty good and they take care to be attentive.    FYI, they may charge a small fee for using ATM/credit cards.  On our last visit, we happened to have cash and noticed it was just a bit cheaper than usual.

QYFVBbdS7rDrn0qZJrLRaw.text: Decisions to eat "rolls" at Asian restaurants usually lead to regret, but not at Lemongrass. Their Vietnamese egg rolls are hot, crisp, thin, lightly fried in fresh oil, and served with a handful of mint. The mint is used to erase guilt you might feel by eating fried food when the menu offers many other healthy options.   The Vietnamese Crepe fascinates me. We ordered the one with shrimp. It's huge and yellow, like an omelet. It's crispy with lots of holes. See Cayenne's instructions on how to properly eat a Vietnamese Crepe. The hot jasmine tea is complimentary; the sweet, rice flavors set it off.  Lots of my buddies are yelping about the Pho. The Pho's good, but I'm no expert. I only eat brothy soups if I'm trying to lose weight.   I would not order the Lotus Salad again because I didn't like the flavor and smell of the pork. The chicken spring rolls are less fabulous than the egg rolls, so I wouldn't waste stomach space on those either.   Service is fantastic. One of the owners helped me choose delicious menu items our first time in. The decor is an odd mix of framed Asian poster prints, beige booths, purple walls and red neon.   Definitely a new favorite.

RY1d1bPQ4m91_F0pTq2oeQ.text: At first, we weren't sure if it was the restaurant since it looked like a 50's diner. I must commend the freshness of pho, #39 small. Although, it took awhile to make the pho, it was all worth it. I took my first sip and I could already tell a major difference! I, for one, could never tell the difference with pho or sushi BUT I could definitely taste it.  We met the owner's niece and she was really friendly. Our first visit, we mentioned yelp and gave us 10% off but now they took it off their website since we always go there at least once a week. After our visit, the bf and I ate 2 more times that same week! It was that good!

gf5rAG9l7YPepFOxEFZFlg.text: The good.. Original dishes (beef tamarind salad with lotus stems was amazing) Good prices Excellent service  The bad.. The place was little dirty. It could use a good cleaning.  I will definitely be coming back.

HEamAKW-gKcyjihJxUUISQ.text: Vegan faux pho! And many other vegan options.... Bahn mi (ask for no mayo), lemongrass tofu w/ rice or vermicelli, tofu spring rolls!   The good news: yes, they have vegan-friendly pho-type soups.  You will not be afraid that they might have accidentally given you meat broth.  The bad news: it tastes like veggie broth, not pho broth. It wasn't spiced in the pho way, to clarify (I already said it doesn't taste like meat!).  No hint of cinnamon, anise, fennel, ginger.  That was disappointing.  The resolution: once I added Sriracha and hoisin and a bunch of lime, it was really tasty.  I very much enjoyed my faux, which had a ton of noodles, nice pieces of lightly fried tofu, and came with nice accoutrements (finely shredded red cabbage, basil, sprouts and hot peppers).  I also tried my friend's lemongrass tofu.  It was very tasty (listed as spicy, but was not spicy spicy.  It was whitepeople spicy at best.)  The veggie soup options are not listed on their dine-in menus, but ARE on the take-out menu, FYI.   The iced tea (just plain iced tea) is really good too, and the servers kept my glass full!  One note: my meatavore friend ordered the bun bo hue', which says pigs feet and blood upon request.  He did not request and still got them, so if you're not into that, double check.  Very reasonably priced, good portion sizes, and very tasty.  Will be back to try the sandwiches soon!

HLyapBWVEuS7tFvN21XuDg.text: I was impressed with the 80-diner theme. Not something you see with Vietnamese restaurant. I thought the waiter was slow in getting our order. And it seem like they're missing all kind of ingredients, which force you to pick another dish. I guess because they open at 10am and we arrived at 10:30am.  My friend found a hair strand in one of her pho. And I ordered Bun Thit Nem Nuong. The nem nuoung was a disappointment.

eThuBh1YjmYpA0Ol2F5KjQ.text: Friendly servers and always a great experience! One of the best places in town to get pho. The prices are good and the food is excellent. Definitely recommend!

z3VTGEHVkytvdqYmQm41EA.text: It may be called Lemongrass Cafe but the outside looks like Mel's Diner.    Seemed like a lot of people in the office were craving pho and I mentioned the 10% off via Yelp and that helped seal the deal for lunch.   The clock outside the restaurant said 9:00 but the place was pretty busy at 2 in the afternoon. I like coming here because the staff is always really friendly, and the pho comes out quick before your done wiping down the soup spoon.  I don't like the short wooden chopsticks they give you, but just my only personal pet peeve.    The Bun Bo Hue here is my favorite and the broth consistently has great flavor. *slurp*.  Pho Dac Biet and Bun Thit Nuong get honorable mention also.    Quick and satisfying.  Pho sho!

fshjynAz1KPickQYOkunfA.text: Good food,  terrible service! Not accommodating what so ever... I'm sorry, but to get a good review from me, good food and good service comes hand in hand and it's  a must! We ordered 2 orders of bun bo hue (spicy noodle soup), yes I get it, it's supposed to be spicy.  I can handle the spice, but my fiance cannot, lol ... of course the noodles arrive and as soon as I tasted it I knew he couldn't handle it... The spice level must have been at least an 8! So when the server comes over and asked if it was OK,  I told her it was too spicy for him, and if they  could remake another bowl for him since he only took two bites. Her reply was that we should have told the server how spicy we wanted it. Umm yea obviously I would have, but the server who took the order did not ask. Mind you my fiance is Vietnamese and his mom makes this dish for us all the time, not to mention we've ordered this many times,  many different restaurants and it's never came out this spicy! So long story short,  the server refuses to remake the bowl and tells us we will be charged double, I told her that makes NO SENSE!  But whatever. ... There are way too many restaurants in Vegas to trip over this one restaurant,  so BYE FELICIA!!!!

xkMRcgfZ-X_9wuBVPX6j_w.text: So I don't do Vietnamese. But I'm trying to be vegetarian.   #59 veggie tofu pho was incredibly fresh. Fresh cut Basil stalks and crispy bean sprouts accompanied a huge bowl of delicious noodles and veggies. It was so incredibly good. I've had fun noodle at Whole Foods and was happy, but for the same price I got twice as much noodles and 3 times the veggies. I'm stuffed eating vegetarian and will be back to try the veggie crepes and veggie curry. Great food in a surprising diner building. Glad I discovered this. Makes it easy to eat healthy veggies and feel full. Maybe I'll lose more weight??

rTvJ_bwp2E2MhZoJHXf4vQ.text: I found my way to the Lemongrass Cafe yesterday as I enlisted the help of Yelp to find a great Vietnamese place in the Silverado Ranch area.  I've driven down Eastern several times in the past few weeks and never would have guessed that 50's diner was a Vietnamese reastuarant plus it's also alittle hidden. If you're not looking for it, you wouldn't even know it's there.Thank you Yelp!  I definitely got my fix on Pho, Bahn Mi and spring rolls. I'm such a piglet, however, I didn't eat everything there. I took the Bahn Mi and srping rolls home for dinner. Yum! And to top that....the place was really clean and the service was excellent. Add to that, the server was the most polite and courteous. She even came back to see how my meal was and as I left she thanked me very much for coming.Could I ask for more? yes....5 minutes from my new home (I just moved here from Seattle last month) and it beats driving into Chinatown.  Thanks for delicious meal Lemongrass Cafe. See you next week!

TOI5pymo2snO8gQOLCM_sw.text: Hidden inside a semi remodeled 50's diner with overgrown weeds and oleanders all out front is the best Pho I have ever eaten. I would have never in a million years given this place a try if it wasn't for my fellow yelpers, just from the outside aesthetics, I would have passed it up.  Ordered the spring rolls for starters, and then ordered the shrimp pho, the broth was so perfect, not salty and it had great flavor. All the veggies were fresh, the bowl was large and I'm not ashamed to say I ate/drank the entire thing. What's even better is it was super cheap! I believe our bill was $25 for 2 teas, 2 pho's and an app. Even in 110 degree heat I'm still dreaming of this lunch I had and I can't wait to go back!

8KaxiRTgufe8HgJRDy09tA.text: Nothing to complain about -delicious and cheap rare beef pho. $6.95 gets you small bowl and for a dollar more you can get a large. We tried the spring rolls and egg rolls, both were OK. 5 stars for the simple fact that their beef pho is a winner, and the added bonus is that it's in an American diner......when can you ever get that experience? Loves it.

jEYA768GVuBlnensb8CtYA.text: It was a cold and rainy day when we wandered into the little silver diner gone Pho house and the weather set the perfect backdrop for some yummy Vietnamese noms. We tried the tofu spring rolls and the veggie broth tofu and veggie pho. It was perfectly delicious and did a great job warming us up.

QWW2Dah6ustUndMLpKJvpg.text: Went here on Friday evening.  I was caught off guard by the "diner" building, but I did not let it deter me.    We started with Banb Mi Chien Tom (Shrimp Toast).  It was really tasty, krispy, and great.  I could not eat meat as it was the last Friday of Lent, so I went with the Shrimp Cheyote.  The waiter looked at me and said "Spicy?"  I said yes.  Then I got worried.  I wondered if it would be too much for me to handle. But, when it came out it was great.  It had a good punch of heat, but I like that.  The shrimp was cooked perfectly!  The bf had the one of the beef Pho dishes, though I cannot remember which.  He really like it.  I did try the broth and it was super flavorful.  This is definitely an unexpected treat!  I would go back in a heartbeat.  Though next time, I am getting meat!

fbUnWAvsJp3D0tlqDQiHeg.text: Over the last 3 or 4 years my fascination with  southern pacific cuisine has increasingly grown and as of today it is stronger than ever.  There's something about southern Asian ingredients that I find to be so exciting, fresh and particularly pleasing to my pallet.  When done right there are few people in the nation eating as good as you, and in Las Vegas the Lemongrass Cafe is home to "done right" Vietnamese cuisine.    The Pho here is the best I've had in Las Vegas.  The rare steak is so flavorful and tender, the noodles are cooked perfectly, just firm enough to taste and feel the texture of every single noodle. The broth is so clean and refreshing just add sprouts, chili paste and hoisin sauce to taste and dig in. Now lets get to the Bahn Mi (Vietnamese Sandwich) WOW PEOPLE, I possibly couldn't think of a better flavor combination than what the hell is going down in one of these bad boys.  The textures and flavors our out of this world. Crunchy baguette, pickled veggies, nicely seasoned pork, and a little bit of heat. This sandwich brings it home with three out of the five food groups in the Leo flavor spectrum ( Crunchy, Pickled, & Porky )

NdvUAUlLfIeOuMsa9AzOEQ.text: There seems to be a lot of Pho restaurants opening up in Las Vegas...on Eastern in particular.  I tried the other places but it doesn't really seem to compare to this one.  Although the decor throws you off a bit as it is a converted 50's diner, the food allows you to look past that.  Yesterday I had the seafood Pho (small) and my husband had the raw meat Pho.  I have to admit my husband is a big fan of this place as well.  My seafood Pho was great...tons of noodles (kinda wished there was more seafood though).  It had crab, fish balls, squid, and shrimp and about 2 of each.  My husband also loved his Pho...he always asks for extra basil on his.  The service was average, our waiter was nice and friendly towards our 4 year old son.  When they first opened they used to give my son a small bowl of noodles with broth; but I guess they don't do that anymore so he had the grilled chicken and steamed rice place which he liked.  The chicken was sliced thin, marinated in a sweet tangy sauce and then grilled.

s05gltc8XthFiuTZMwVTIg.text: Their spring rolls with pork and shrimp were no good. Absolutely no flavor at all that even the subpar peanut sauce could not save them. Save your money and go elsewhere!

XVeBmbg6_OaQDhRbo9k6LA.text: I love the Bun Bo Hue at this place. I can say the best in town. Enough spices and herbs to make the broth tasty and filling. I been going here at least once every week until one incident and I stopped. Every time I dine I order the same thing. Older lady I believe ewner recognises me and knows my order. I took a couple of friends highly recommending this restaurant as my favourite. I ordered the same Bun Bo Hue. When the noodles came it was the wrong noodles it was egg noodle instead of the thicker rice noodles. I told the lady sorry these noodles are not the noodles I wanted. She gave me such an attitude saying that's what you ordered I'm not changing it so if you want new noodles I'll charge you. It's not even the noodles or the price at this point. I have been a loyal guest and maybe I made the mistake or she heard wrong but to speak to me in such a way was outright poor customer service. She said you ordered the wrong noodles not my fault. Wow! Is all I'm going to say. No matter how good this restaurant is I will never go back. Service has always been bad water given is slammed on the tables. No smiles not friendly. I go there to try to relax and enjoy the food and friends not to be treated like some homeless person.

Q_od8zNCdmcfuh-HNYOPaw.text: I'm not sure why this place doesn't have better reviews!!!! This HAS to be the best vietnamese food you can get in Vegas....  Honestly,  everything I've had here (pho, banh mi, egg rolls, spring rolls, rice dishes and even this one shrimp mango salad dish) have been deliciously tantalizing!! They got their flavoring down. Their prices aren't too bad either!!! If you want authentic vietnamese food,  you gotta come here.  It's almost as good as the ones in LA and that says a lot in my opinion!! Don't let the old diner look fool you,  this place is a hidden gem!!

HiURY423traRBqTpFruUrQ.text: I absolutely HATE THE SERVICE HERE!! The lack of customer service is unwelcoming and borderline disrespectful. On every.single.visit!!Wether it's dine in or take out!   The food is good and it's in my neighborhood so that's why I always come here.   Only the elderly woman is nice. I think she's the owner. She's the ONLY ONE there that makes you feel welcomed and doesn't give you an attitude when you ask for something, e.g. check, extra sauce, limes, napkins, water refills and even the check!   Now back to the food. The food is good. But I wouldn't be surprised if you annoy them and ask for extra sauce they give you "extra sauce" if you know what I mean....

Jgv-WTSQ1_tApR00EDg9KA.text: This is a great place for Pho! The portions sizes are huge!   Can't wait to go back!

Jjy57K4HkejyubGveugawA.text: Had a craving for pho. Glad I stopped by here. Noodles and broth was perfect. So was my toppings. Highly recommend this place if your into Pho. Fast service and clean.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass Café - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Combination pho

shIvvoh55IYCOF1CPHd2ZA.text: I really enjoy coming to Lemongrass Cafe for my Vietnamese food craves now. I have ordered during lunch, dinner, weekends, and weekdays and the food has been just so consistent. The service has been fast and friendly and if I don't have time to wait a little I can always call ahead for pick up. I love their pho dac biet ( special pho ). The broth is always flavorful, well seasoned, and never greasy. They always provide generous helpings of fresh Thai basil, bean sprouts, a wedge of lime and jalepeno even in the to go orders, so I feel like I have the dining portion at home. Winning! I ordered some egg rolls this time around and a side of fresh romaine lettuce, sprigs of mint and fresh dipping sauce came with it. I thought to myself, "What do I do with all this veggie stuff?" Then I realized you use the romaine lettuce leaf to wrap around the egg roll so that your hands don't get oily. Brilliant! And if you like, you can add the mint in the lettuce wrap for extra brightness in flavor. The dipping sauce was fish sauce with some chili and lime. It was a perfect compliment to the egg roll lettuce wrap. I didn't notice till later that they cut extra ventilation holes in the to-go box for the freshly made egg rolls so that it wouldn't get soggy. Little details like that says they take pride in their food tasting the way it should be. Fresh and made with love. Highly recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass Café - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Finished product. Iced Vietnamese coffee. Yaass!
Photo of Lemongrass Café - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Vietnamese iced coffee. So legit!
Photo of Lemongrass Café - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Clean counter area with Asian decor.

iidCEhJcdr_eqkqHxR6-Jg.text: After 3 years here, we don't bother going anywhere else for Vietnamese food. Everything is just done very well, with quality here. And today I discovered spicy beef soup, wow, unbelievable.  The spiciness is not overwhelming but might make your nose runny. It does include some pork meat in there as well. And the beef reminds me of a Mexican cocido, so good!

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass Café - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy beef soup

pZkg0Y-KM9PrsBf4HTIJ0w.text: The only reason i give them 2stars is because the service!!! If i can give them 0 i would.. for the service alone.. the food though.. DELICIOUS!!!! i come here so often and also walked out couple times.. so now i dont even bother dining in anymore, i just call and pick it up so i dont have to deal with shitty attitude. Again FOOD IS ALWAYS EXCELLENT... SERVICE SUCKS!!!

nNJxfKMFd1FfYq7suJ51zw.text: Always the best when I go here! Friendly staff, amazing Pho, and would highly recommend to anyone. Update! I look my boyfriend on our first date here about 7 months ago and it has not gotten old. The staff knows us so well we walk in and sit and they already know our order (we like what we like). They have never been rude or impatient. Even when my bill was lower then $10 they would still let me use my debit card. I also like that they don't check on me a million times. I came to eat not socialize with them. They get it and it's great! Try the chicken pho or lemongrass chicken, to die for!!!

LvI5BTOicOIcQVLu7nagng.text: I've been here twice recently.  It's located in a cute little 50s style diner. My visit last week turned into a to-go order request, due to the lack of alcohol available (Yelp says they have beer and wine, but they don't currently.) I ordered #42 Pho Chin Nam (well done brisket and flank) and they packaged everything beautifully for me to take home and assemble at home.  So the meat and all the condiments were packaged separately from the broth, and it was a breeze to put together and reheat a little on the stove top.  Divine flavors from everything!  Today I had lunch with my son, and we ordered three different banh mi sandwiches.  They have several choices of meat.  I had the grilled pork, my son had the pork sausage and also the fried egg.  Excellent! Their prices are inexpensive and all the ingredients are very fresh.  I will definitely be returning.

s70t62XwzZJH-dnDJM6kzg.text: I have tasted Combination Pho from different pho establishments and have always needed hoisin sauce to complement the taste. But at Lemongrass, their Combination Pho was incredibly delicious ---I didnt need to add anything!! Go for the large size for $1 more. Totally worth it. Had it for lunch and it was still yummy for dinner :)

u0W-VfIvznC53ZYbhci25g.text: Awsome food and excellent service, the male waiter is cool. I come here at least once a week, they have variety choice. Never been disappointed EVER.

UJRqNZZxXArhVy-lt3EUnA.text: The food is fantastic and the little diner-looking restaurant is adorable from the inside and out. The only reason I give this place a 4 though is because everyone who works here is so unfriendly. I don't think I've ever seen someone smile there

_mChEaWwKH10H_SoSrQo1A.text: Who would've thought an establishment specializing in Vietnamese cuisine could be actually found inside what appears to be an old school 50s diner?  Glad to have given it a shot as it's become one of my go-to spots in this side of the valley for years.  This restaurant, not only offers dishes on the menu that others don't, but also has food that's far tastier than its competitors.  Too bad that's the only good part left since everything else in this place has certainly gone downhill from my first time dining here.  I have to say, my last visit was rather upsetting.  My group and I were seated by a server who'd rather be doing anything else but her job as we were greeted with a frown and expressed little-to-no concern of how we're doing.  We then decided to move around twice due to this horrid stench coming from each tabletop; must've been that old dish rag used multiple times without being replaced.  I also noticed how the menus are terribly out of date with either marked up prices written all over or random items crossed off.  Overall, Lemongrass is definitely one of the better Vietnamese restaurants in the valley.  However, it's current state left me questioning if it's still even safe to eat here since the place is just dirty.  I know some may attribute this to authenticity as some places in Vietnam where one can get amazing meals aren't in the greatest shape, but this is a different country and everybody in the food industry should be held responsible to a higher level of expectation.  I'd start looking for an alternative if I were you.

TIAHQgEBQyTgyVZEi7hSlg.text: I had just got off the plane to sin city and had a hankering for some pho. Nothing fancy, no buffet or big juicy steak, just some pho. I used my yelp app and found this place just a few miles from the airport. While driving there I almost missed it because my gps seemed off ( pointing to the other side of the street). We figured it was on the OTHER side of the street and when going into the shopping center almost missing it because the physical location was in HHS form of Silver Diner. I mean one doesn't expect to see a Vietnamese joint in the form of an old 50's style diner. At least put a guy in a rice hat squatting out front cooking some fish over a some charcoal to make it more obvious.   I'm just kidding about that....he should be squatting and smoking a cigarette.  I was wondering if Alice or Flo were gonna take our order and then we'd see Mel throw a couple of bowls of pho in the kitchen window and (DING!) yell "PICKUP!". If you didn't get that reference you're too dam young or you didn't grow up here.  Moving on. The inside does have the look and feel of an old diner. It almost feels like its a double wide trailer. I like it. We were seated right away at a table by the window with  comfy chairs. They have a big menu. With lots of choices. Noodle(vermicelli) dishes with BBQ pork, chicken or cat. Just kidding, dog. Haha! Beef dammit. There's something about the way Vietnamese prepare their meat, it tastes fresh, sweet and has that nice char.  A good selection of appetizers like spring rolls ( made with rice paper and not fried), but also some fried rolls. They had some banh mi, those sanwhiches on a baguette with pork, cilantro, pickled carrots and radish. Plenty of rices dishes, if you didn't care for noodles.  And of course, what I came for, pho. Which I ordered with rare beef flank, tendons and tripe. That's right, give me that pink and nasty gushy stuff. I also ordered some homemade pork sausage spring rolls. Which were pretty frickin awesome. The sausage was grilled so it had a crispy outside and then thinly sliced. There was an element that I never had in a fresh spring roll as well, they put a stick of fried won ton wrapper inside, that gave it that extra crunch when biting into it. It was like eating a fried roll....but not. I washed that down with a glass of freshly squeezed limeade. Served in a tall fountain glass with extra long spoon.   Then they brought the pho out. (I like how they waited for us to finish the appetizer first). The broth was good, but I needed to add some chilli sauce for that extra kick. Threw in the fresh basil off the twig, sprouts and jalepenos and BOOM I was very satisfied. After slurping on it like I was eating some late night macaroni and cheese, I reached the bottom of the bowl. All done. Take my money I'm out.   The service was good and I feel like they had some kind of edge serving out of that diner.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass Café - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pho with beef flank, tendon and tripe.

If47PTY_-jEPtlyVOIShRQ.text: My first time at lemongrass was sometime in 2009. Since then, its changed owners a few times.   The big bowls of pho and decent  prices havent changed though. Im not a huge consumer of pho, but the broth here is pretty tasty.   I order a 39, i believe which is the rare meat, and it was very tender. We ordered a combination bah mi sandwich,  150, homemade sausage, an order of spring rolls...and a few other bowls of non pho.   The older couple that seems to be the owners were very kind. Never had to hunt anyone down for water, or forks or anything like that.   I dont understand  why they only seat in one part of the restaurant. ..and i do agree  that the tables filled with mail, paper and god only  knows what is a little off putting.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass Café - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sausage
Photo of Lemongrass Café - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Broth.

xbM1taG8cCnGBP7DCk69PA.text: One of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants and it's close to home (Henderson)! They have a pretty large selection on their menu and the service has been good every time. I usually get their Seafood Pho or the Bun Tom Nuong. Yum!!!
